section: The exclusive purpose of the Venture (the "Purpose") will be IT Development. internet Back office Maintenance And Deployment of medical Service. This purpose may be changed at any time at the discretion of BorrowMoney.com, inc.
explanation: The initial statement defines the venture's purpose as IT development and related services for medical services. However, the subsequent sentence grants BorrowMoney.com, inc. the unilateral right to change this purpose at any time. This creates a contradiction because it undermines the initial agreement on the venture's purpose and gives one member unchecked authority to alter the fundamental nature of the venture without the consent of the other member, JVLS, LLC dba Vaccines 2Go.

section: Duties of Members Description BorrowMoney.com, inc *HTML code, build, deploy and maintain all technical aspect requirements including a database for medical dispatch personal & product service as needed, including activity information, data storage and backup. provided by three qualified assigned Borrowmoney.com, inc. employees/personal JVLS, LLC dba Vaccines 2Go $60,000.00 USD From Monthly Government , City And State, And Or Private Awarded Contracts. Plus (10%) Of Any Generated Gross Revenue From Awarded Contract, In Addition to The Total Contributions.
explanation: The asterisk before 'HTML code' introduces an ambiguity. It is unclear what the asterisk refers to, if anything, and its presence disrupts the clarity of the outlined responsibilities. It creates an in-text contradiction because it's an unexplained symbol in a section meant to clearly define member duties.

section: Each of the Members has contributed to the capital of the Venture, in cash or property in agreed upon value, as follows (the "Capital Contribution"): Member Contribution Description Agreed Value BorrowMoney.com, inc 1, 500 square feet of Leased/rent office Space Includingspecified Description of duty* $3,500,000.00 USD JVLS, LLC dba Vaccines 2Go $60,000.00 USD From Monthly Government , City And State, And Or Private Awarded Contracts. Plus (10%) Of Any Generated Gross Revenue, In Add i t i on to The To ta l Contributions. $3,500,000.00 USD
explanation: JVLS, LLC dba Vaccines 2Go is contributing $60,000 from monthly awarded contracts in addition to 10% of any generated gross revenue. The word 'contributions' means that the $60,000 and 10% is contributed as the agreed value, but the agreed value states $3,500,000.

section: Any vote required by the Members will be determined such that each Member receives one vote, however, BorrowMoney.com, inc.'s vote will carry twice the weight of JVLS, LLC dba Vaccines 2Go's vote.
explanation: This statement presents a contradiction because it undermines the principle of equal voting rights between members. While it states each member receives one vote, it then modifies this by giving BorrowMoney.com, inc.'s vote twice the weight of JVLS, LLC's vote. This creates a situation where one member's vote has significantly more influence than the other, effectively violating the initial statement of equal voting rights.

section: This Agreement may be amended with the consent of BorrowMoney.com, inc., notwithstanding any objection from JVLS, LLC dba Vaccines 2Go.
explanation: This clause creates a significant imbalance of power and a legal contradiction. It allows BorrowMoney.com, Inc. to unilaterally amend the agreement, regardless of JVLS, LLC's objections. This contradicts the fundamental principle of mutual agreement in contract law. Amendments should generally require consent from all parties involved. This clause essentially nullifies JVLS, LLC's input on any changes to the agreement, potentially leading to unfair or detrimental outcomes for them.

section: On the liquidation of the Venture assets, distribution of any amounts to Members will be made in proportion to their respective capital accounts or as otherwise may be agreed in writing.
explanation: The initial part of the sentence states that liquidation proceeds will be distributed in proportion to the members' respective capital accounts. However, the phrase "or as otherwise may be agreed in writing" introduces ambiguity. It implies that the distribution can deviate from the proportion of capital accounts if a written agreement dictates otherwise. This creates a contradiction because it's unclear which method of distribution takes precedence. If a written agreement exists, does it supersede the capital account proportions, or does it need to be unanimously agreed upon to be valid? This lack of clarity leads to potential disputes during liquidation.
